title: Tuesday, 17th January, 2017

The details of May's speech were dropped to the press this morning so I'm not sure there's a rabbit left there.

11:06 am

Bats

BE11:06am

BATS!

PM11:06am

11:06 am

And it didn't collapse!

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 4,747, down 15.6 (-0.33%), High: 4,820, Low: 4,744, Volume: 1.92m
BE11:07am

It's a slightly dull $50bn deal, truth be told.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

7% bump to rejected price, more cash involved.

BE11:07am

Which is almost exactly what the consensus had moved up to ahead of time.

BE11:08am

In spite of StreetInsider and the like making vague noises about things stalling, and scribblers speculating about clarity on tax and valuations of vape pipes and etc.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

At this price, it looks neutral.

BE11:09am

Let me get some sellside to say "it looks neutral"

PM11:09am

great

11:10 am
BE11:10am

RBC

BE11:10am

British American Tobacco has announced that it has agreed the terms of a recommended offer to buy the remaining 57.8% of Reynolds American it currently does not own. The transaction has been approved by the Boards of BAT and Reynolds.

The new offer consists of $29.44 in cash and 0.5260 BAT shares for each Reynolds’ share, valuing the company at $59.64 per share, a 7% increase vs the original offer and a 26% premium to Reynolds' closing price on 20 October 2016. Assuming $400m cost synergies realized over three years, our DCF valuation for Reynolds American returns a fair value of $59, meaning that the deal is about value neutral (“Camel’s Back”, October 2016).

On our pro-forma estimates assuming full realization of the synergies, we estimate EPS enhancement of 5.1% (the company is guiding for mid single-digits in year 3), ROIC post-synergies of 4.2% and Net Debt/EBITDA of 3.4x (with the company committed to go back down to around 3.0x by the end of 2019).

The new offer confirms our initial take on the deal. We think it makes sense strategically and operationally and just about washes its face financially. That said, a value neutral acquisition does little to alter our view that the shares are already reasonably valued.

PM11:11am

That's a very balanced take

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Most of the sellside feels .... how do I say this politely? .... a bit pre-written.

BE11:12am

Which is understandable given the circumstances. Here's Barclays.

BE11:12am

Strategic rationale:

1.) it provides direct access to the attractive and cash generative US market;

· 2.) it balances BAT’s global cash flow streams between Emerging and Developing markets;

· 2.) it enhances BAT’s global brand portfolio;

· 3.) it establishes the only truly global Next Generation Product company.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Financials: EPS and DPS accretive in Year 1

BAT has confirmed that it will deliver at least $400m of cost synergies from the deal within three years, in-line with those out-lined in its original proposal. Management have also stated that they expect the deal to be EPS and DPS accretive in the first full year post completion (2018), MSD accretive by year 3 and that they will beat a US WACC by year 5. BAT expects the transaction to enhance BAT cash generation and the group has committed to maintaining a dividend payout of at least 65% following closing. Bank financing for the deal is already in place and BAT will look to issue bonds in due course. Net debt/EBITDA to reach 3.0x by 2019. Subject to regulatory approval, the deal is expected to close in Q3 17.

BE11:13am

Valuation: BAT re-rating likely in time

BAT is trading on a CY 17E PE of 16.8x and Reynolds trades on 18.3x. However, [...] given the increased exposure to the US, we believe the combined BAT/RAI business could trade on a c.1.0x higher PE multiple than standalone BAT.

BE11:13am

11:13 am
PM11:14am

It really is balanced, geographically

BE11:15am

It's been interesting watching the move from wanting ciggies in emerging markets (for growth) to wanting ciggies in mature markets (for ... stability I guess? Or clarity of regulation?)

BE11:15am

Most clearly visible in the rerating for Imperial Tobacco Brands Whatever, of course.

undefined
PM11:16am

So Rolls has finally settled this bribery stuff

This story seems to have been running for most of my adult life

BE11:16am

Expensively!

BE11:16am

It's been a while, yes.

PM11:16am

Yeah, i thought it expensive as well

11:16 am
BE11:16am

To recap .....

PM11:16am

http://www.investe...1701161654552892U/

BE11:16am

..... Deferred prosecution agreement with the UK, Brazil, and the US to close bribery and corruption allegations for a total cost of £671m over up to five years.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Compare that with BAE in February 2010. They pleaded guilty and had to pay $400m to the DOJ and £30m to the SFO.

BE11:18am

Rolls, by contrast, pays £497.2m to the SFO (plus interest)

BE11:18am

DOJ gets $169.9m

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Where does the money go?

PM11:18am

Specifically the 500m to the SFO over five years (plus interest)

PM11:18am

There's serious funding for the SFO, if it gets to keep it

11:18 am
BE11:19am

.... and $25.6m goes to the MPF. I don't know where the cash goes. It's a good question.

BE11:19am

Perhaps the SFO Christmas party will be a good one this year.

PM11:19am

Buy lots of second rate coppers and accountants with that amount of dosh

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Dunno. Here's Berenberg with a very very long summary, in case you want it.

PM11:19am

er, ok

BE11:19am

● Payment schedule: Under the terms of the agreements, Rolls-Royce will make a payment to the DoJ totalling $169.9m and to the MPF totalling $25.6m. Under the terms of the DPA with the SFO, which is set for final judicial review today, Rolls-Royce has agreed to pay £497.2m plus interest under a schedule lasting up to five years, alongside a payment in respect of the SFO’s costs. The total of the first year payment is c£293m with, we presume, around c£100m per annum payable in each of the next four years.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

● £671m is a significant sum: We suspect the figure is much larger than anyone had anticipated (including us). The allegations and investigations which are linked to the use of intermediaries in certain international sales campaigns have been hanging over the company since they first came to light in 2012. There has been little news of late other than the obligatory statement in the results release that the investigations are ongoing and that the company is fully cooperating. Hence, it is unlikely that the threat of a penalty or settlement was in the forefront of investors’ minds before last night. Given the scale of the settlement, this announcement is clearly a significant negative surprise. The shares will react negatively.

BE11:20am

"The shares will react negatively" somehow ignored the reverse profit warning in there, to which they're reacting positively.

BE11:20am

● But the settlement is affordable: £671m represents 5.5% of Rolls-Royce’s market cap and compares to our forecast net debt at the end of 2016 of £578m. The balance sheet is far from being stretched (net debt/EBITDA 0.4x on depressed 2016 profits), and hence the financing and scheduling of payments do not present a major problem, in our view. However, for a company wrestling with multiple operational challenges, and that needs to fund a c€720m buy-out of the ITP joint venture in 2017, such a development is clearly unwelcome.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

● Further risks? There is little detail about the specifics of the agreements and we recall other accusations that have surfaced in the past few years, such as those related to Indonesia and
China. More details will emerge from the final judicial review today but we suspect agreement with the UK and US authorities represents the closure of the bulk of litigation risk attached to these issues. Notwithstanding the scale of the sums, it is mildly positive that these issues are now largely behind the company.
● FY16 ahead: Even more positive, and partly mitigating the negative sentiment attached to Monday’s revelation, is the company’s comment that it “has had a good finish to the year with both profit and, in particular, cash expected to be ahead of expectations”. The company had guided to profit headwinds in 2016 of c£650m and FCF of between £0 and -£300m. It will deliver full year results on 14 February.

PM11:21am

We should note the share price reaction tho

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 713.00, up 48 (+7.22%), High: 715.00, Low: 688.50, Volume: 6.37m
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Yes, the reverse profit warning is important here

BE11:22am

Given last year had .... five, was it? .... non-reverse profit warnings.

BE11:22am

Plus clarity, plus affordability, drawing lines, yada yada.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Have some Sandy Morris at Jefferies

BE11:23am

Who was unlucky enough to set up a 27 page note about Rolls' FX exposure to publish this morning .....

BE11:23am

Sandy's a smart chap, though, so he's bundled it all together thematically in a catch-up note.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Dollar Academy. Today’s longer note sees us revisit how to set forecasts for Civil Aerospace underlying revenue. Reported revenue is more influenced by the short-term path of the US$
£ and, to a lesser extent, the US$€ (Business Aviation), but underlying revenue is essentially dictated by the achieved US$£ rate, a proxy for which is the average rate in the US$£ hedge book, give or take a few cents. So far, we have not consciously included a positive FX transaction impact in our forecasts for Civil Aerospace EBIT and FCF, but the approach we have adopted to set revenue has highlighted the latent positive effect should the achieved US$£ rate improve by, say, two US$ cents per annum through to 2020. Were 2020 net US$ income to be around US$6bn and were the achieved US$£ rate to evolve from an estimated US$1.60/£ in 2016 to US$1.50/£ in 2020, the benefit to FCF would be around £250m, in our view.

BE11:23am

Probabilities. We consider it unlikely sterling will rally strongly against the US$ while Brexit is underway, but the nature of FX is such that we would rather a more favourable US$/£ transaction FX was secure in the hedge book before we reflect the potential positive impact in our forecasts for EBIT (complicated by IFRS15) and FCF (less complicated). By mid-2017, we might, however, have to change. Not today though. Today, the change to our forecasts – 2016 forecast EBIT is raised from £730m to £795m – largely reflects positive FX translation.

BE11:24am

Our forecasts for FCF are unchanged. The change made to forecast 2016 EBIT does not – obviously - reflect the comment made by RR about it having a good finish to 2016.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

DPA: In December 2012, RR reported to the SFO concerns about bribery and corruption involving intermediaries in overseas markets. In December 2013, the SFO launched an investigation. The more time elapsed, the more probable it became the concerns would prove serious, but we venture it unlikely that a penalty as great as £673m (around 37p a share) had been factored into expectations. Agreements have been reached with the SFO, US DoJ and Brazil’s MPF. In the first year of all three agreements, total payments by RR will be £293m. We note, that this theoretically allows for some part of the £293m to fall in FY2018, but the key point is that £380m of payments fall subsequently, perhaps as late as 2021. We believe that materially lowers the stress that the agreement places on RR’s balance sheet, certainly if our postulation of a £250m transaction FX benefit to 2020 FCF proves to have substance.

BE11:24am

Healing. More about the DPA and – of course – 2016 EBIT and FCF, will be revealed on 14 February 2017. Meantime, while slightly aghast at the scale of the DPA, we find ourselves with no pressing need to rush to change forecasts for underlying EBIT and, far more importantly, FCF, even taking the DPA into account. Indeed, if transaction FX emerges as we think possible, there may be upside to our forecasts for FCF looking three or four years ahead. We do not know what weighs most heavily with credit rating agencies, but we can see no compelling reason for an automatic downgrade. Critics may argue the potential positive transaction FX effect is not secure; precisely why we have not changed our forecasts today. Critics may also suggest RR has enjoyed a stroke of good fortune. Again, we would not strongly disagree. Nonetheless, the DPA and the “good finish” to 2016 may well suggest RR has started to make its own luck. We think that could be quite significant.

BE11:25am

That's the theme. Drawing lines, moving on. Sorry about the alleged bribery, here's a lot of money, let's concentrate on fixing engines.

BE11:31am

11:31 am

BE11:32am

Guess so. Awaiting May etc.

BE11:33am

Jordan Rochester of Nomura -- yes, there are still people at Nomura! -- has just dropped over a very brief May preview.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

If the leaks are proven true, the UK will not seek partial membership of the EU, associate membership or anything that leaves us half in or half out. So no single market access or customs union and we should expect immigration controls and no more ECJ for the UK.

Then there are a few other questions to ask that will act as small headline events, such as EU/UK noises on a transitional deal and/or what access the UK will seek for certain sectors but then we get to a scenario where the market is pricing a Hard Brexit outcome with 100% certainty.

Does that then see the bottom in GBP? In the short term, perhaps, but we are inclined to see GBP remain a sell on rallies but would be selective as to how to express it.

The price action this morning have some concerned that a short squeeze is possible given all the bad news is priced in. Perhaps, but this is not over as we still have the fragile flow picture in the UK that demands a weaker currency (and higher UK yields) to offset the CA deficit that grows wider and wider as UK consumption remains solid. Whilst the USD is weak this morning it acts as a reminder than GBPUSD is perhaps not the best way to play the trade (thanks to Trumps weak dollar policy concerns). We prefer the likes of EURGBP higher (initially targeting the 0.90 level) and GBPNZD lower (target 1.65).

Ive got one of those UBS Q&A thingies you love so much Bryce

PM11:42am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Q4 sales are €1,086-1,094m (cons €1,121m) implying 25-26% sales growth. This gives FY sales of €3,633-3,642m (cons €3,679m) implying growth of 22.9-23.1% (cons 24%) and compared to their guidance for the "upper end of the 20-25% range". Q4 adjusted EBIT is between €81-104m v cons €83m giving a margin of 7.5-9.5%. For the FY adj EBIT will be €202-225m v cons €204m and UBS €202m implying a c.5% beat.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Q4 sales were up less than expected which was surprising given revenue beats from Boohoo and ASOS as margin looks to have been traded for revenue growth or, as a bigger business, Zalando trades in a similar way to the underlying clothing market.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: FY17 guidance released on 1 March and this is where we differ from consensus.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We think the sales will disappoint but the 5% margin beat may offset this. In our view with the strong recent performance the weaker sales performance will disappoint.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

I do like them! They're pitched at exactly my attention span.

PM11:42am

BE11:42am

11:42 am

PM11:43am

11:44 am
BE11:44am

What does it all mean?
For 4Q, Zalando’s preliminary results imply revenues in the range €1,086-€1,094 mn (+25%-26% yoy) and adj. EBIT in the range €81-104 mn (7 .5%-9.5% margin). At the midpoint, revenues are c.4% below consensus expectations of €1,138 mn, and adj. EBIT is 5% ahead of consensus of €88 mn (GSe: €1,130 mn in revenues and €83.3 mn in adj. EBIT).
In our view, while growth in 4Q was weaker than expected, we see c.25%-26% as strong in the context of the weak apparel market in which pure-play online models are gaining share and accelerating growth. Note Zalando’s 3Q revenue growth was 17%. Peer ASOS’s EU segment accelerated to +38% (cFX, 4 months to December
31 vs. 30% in the prior 2m period), and Boohoo’s RoE segment +54%, cFX, 4-months to December 31 vs. +40% in the prior 3m period.

BE11:44am

Implications
We expect small positive changes to consensus adj. EBIT estimates given a midpoint c. 3% ahead of current forecasts, despite slightly lower revenues. Taken together with a strong share price performance ytd (+9%) and over the past month

BE11:44am

So ....... meh.

Downgrading ratings: We downgrade the testing companies given headwinds to near term growth, potential disruption to international trade and relative valuation. While we continue to see improving mid-term operational performance from the TIC companies we see better value elsewhere in the sector. We downgrade SGS to Neutral (from Outperform) and Intertek and Bureau Veritas to Underperform (from Neutral and Outperform respectively)

11:49 am
PM11:50am

(Theresa's arrived at Lancaster House)

BE11:50am

Relative valuation: The testing companies, on average, trade above average on both an absolute PE and EV/EBITA basis. Relative to the market, however, they are trading below average levels. This reflects, we think, the lack of organic growth. While we expect organic growth to stabilise in H117 and improve during H217 we do not think the improved momentum is sufficient to support current ratings. This is particularly the case given increased uncertainty around the geo-political backdrop supporting global trade flows and the ongoing pressure in oil and gas markets.

BE11:50am

Growth stabilising: Our more negative ratings are primarily a relative call within the sector given our view that other stocks in the sector offer greater value at this point. In the mid-term we expect that organic growth rates will improve as headwinds from resources operations abate and, into 2018, begin to support growth. This will, along, with ongoing efficiency programs support margin accretion. However we think that near term organic revenue and profit growth will be subdued and this will dominate the share prices.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

Stocks: We downgrade Bureau Veritas and Intertek to Underperform with new price targets of €17 and 3200p, respectively. We downgrade SGS to Neutral with a new Sfr2050 price target and our relatively more positive view reflects the prospect of stronger organic growth, greater mid-term margin opportunity and our expectation for additional share buybacks through 2017E
